text: As I said. We have just traveled from there. Until we met Rafiel, we didn't know there were countries on this side of the desert. After all, no one had ever crossed the Desert of Death and lived to tell of it. Without Rafiel's guidance, we would never have survived the crossing.

speaker: Rafiel
text: My people, the heron clan of Serenes, were blamed for the murder of Begnion's empress. Begnion mobs rose up in rage and massacred them. I had thought the whole of my clan, my entire race, had been wiped out. I wandered the desert in despair. If not for the queen, I would have died. In Hatari, I vowed to dedicate my life to her. And yet every night for these past three years, a voice has called out to me. Day by day, it has grown stronger... Until the voice led me to you all. Your news brings such joy! Father...Reyson...Leanne... My beloved family... My thanks to thee, O goddess... Ah...

speaker: Nailah
text: Rafiel... You talk too much. Control yourself. You, beorc... What's the best route to Gallia?

speaker: Sothe
text: For a group of laguz, traveling through the Daein countryside would be suicide. It will take you longer, but we could take you as far as Crimea.

speaker: Nailah
text: We would be grateful. By all means, let's travel together. But why go to Crimea? Why not travel directly to Gallia?

speaker: Sothe
text: Entering Gallia by yourselves would be nearly impossible. The man you need to get you into Gallia actually resides in Crimea. That man, Ike, is in contact with King Caineghis and his advisors. There's no doubt in my mind that he's the man you need.

speaker: Micaiah
text: Right. Lord Ike, "hero" of the Crimean Liberation, leader of the Greil Mercenaries, and father of Sothe's children...

speaker: Ranulf
text: Now, our next target is Mugill. Its gate is already sealed, and it looks like they intend to keep it that way. This won't go as easily as our battle in Felirae.

speaker: Skrimir
text: Yaawwwwn... Beorc are all the same. We will run them down, just as before.

speaker: Ranulf
text: Skrimir, please... Listen. Just this once.

speaker: Ike
text: What do you think, Soren?

speaker: Soren
text: The Felirae survivors will have warned Mugill of our advance. That's so obvious, even you must have anticipated it. You don't have a plan?

speaker: Skrimir
text: Do not mock me, beorc boy. Why should I bother with plans? No soldier would cower behind stone walls after being challenged to a battle! We will issue a challenge, and they will meet it. We have no need for plans!

speaker: Soren
text: Do you realize how completely absurd you sound? The enemy did not build the fortress so they could stand outside of it. They will not come out of their own accord.

speaker: Skrimir
text: But-- Those beorc cowards! They will hide from us?! What do we do? I do not know how to fight cowards!

speaker: Ranulf
text: Don't you get it? That's what we're trying to decide! Think, Skrimir. Just try.

speaker: Skrimir
text: No! That's your job, Ranulf! You're my second in command. Think of a way for me to use my strength! Anything else is a waste of time. I'll be training outside. Tell me when you have a "plan."

speaker: Ranulf
text: Wait, Skrimir!

speaker: Soren
text: ...This is ridiculous. I'm amazed that someone was desperate enough to make that fool a general.

speaker: Ranulf
text: I'm tempted to agree with you on that. But there's a reason he's here.

speaker: Ranulf
text: Never in its history has Gallia invaded another country. We don't have any experience or tactics to fall back on for this. On top of that, our general... well, you've seen it yourself. Skrimir... He doesn't pay attention to details, nor does he strategize. Sadly, it's not just Skrimir. Most laguz are the same. They're arrogant and stubborn. It doesn't even occur to them that they won't be able to power through the beorc forever.

speaker: Ike
text: Why isn't Caineghis leading the army?

speaker: Ranulf
text: It's not an option. We aren't mobile like the bird tribes. Once we leave our lands, it isn't easy for us to get back. We can't take our king away from his domain.

speaker: Ike
text: Well, what about Giffca, then? There have to be other capable generals in Gallia.

speaker: Ranulf
text: Yeah, you'd think General Giffca would lead, but... Giffca has other duties to attend to, so really, that just leaves Skrimir.

speaker: Soren
text: I understand. Laguz choose their leaders based on strength. If Skrimir is to be the next king, this war is the best opportunity for him to learn about strategy.

speaker: Ranulf
text: Exactly. Since that's the case, we need all the help we can get. Please, lend us your wisdom. Without your help, this war's outcome is certain.

speaker: Ike
text: You can count on us, Ranulf.

speaker: Titania
text: We've told you already. We're here to help.

speaker: Titania
text: Soren, say something!

speaker: Ranulf
text: Well, well. Looks like your strategist isn't fond of laguz yet.

speaker: Titania
text: I'm sorry, Ranulf. he's gotten better, but...

speaker: Ike
text: Soren, Ranulf helped us out. On top of that, he's our client. It's our turn to return the favor, and our job to do it right. Got that?

speaker: Soren
text: ...Fine. But it'll cost you more.

speaker: Ranulf
text: Thanks, all of you. We appreciate the help.

speaker: Soren
text: Give me some time to myself. I'll come up with a plan to get us through this mess.

speaker: Ike
text: Great. We're counting on you, Soren.

speaker: Soren
text: I know. I'll do what I can.

speaker: Begnion
text: Tch! These sub-humans don't know how much trouble they're causing! We can't go anywhere!

speaker: Begnion
text: Tell me about it. Just yesterday, we could've gone out for drinks and had ourselves a merry old time.

speaker: Begnion
text: Fortunately, we have enough food. They'll give up if we hold out long enough.

speaker: Mist
text: Um... Sorry we're late!

speaker: Begnion
text: Who are you? Why are you outside? The city is under lockdown! You need permission to leave your homes!

speaker: Mist
text: What? Well, that's weird. We were told to hand out food to all the watchmen.

speaker: Begnion
text: Wh-what?

speaker: Mist
text: Well, I guess this isn't the place. Should we head back? We don't want the food to spoil...

speaker: Begnion
text: W-wait! Don't go! You don't have to head back. That food is for us. We're sure of it!

speaker: Mist
text: Oh, wonderful! Would you call everyone, then? I'll pass out the food and drinks.

speaker: Ike
text: Looks like the watchmen are all asleep. Great job, everyone.

speaker: Soren
text: The first step is done. Next, we clear out the remaining guards and open the main gate.

speaker: Ike
text: Ranulf and his troops are waiting outside for us. Let's go!

speaker: Begnion
text: Wh-who are you?!

speaker: Begnion
text: Sub-humans! What's going on?! What happened to the lookout?!

speaker: Rommit
text: Stand your ground! Our reinforcements will be here soon. Hold fast until they arrive!

speaker: Grandmother
text: The sub-humans are attacking us? Oh no! This can't be happening! You're a mercenary, right? Please, you have to save us! We'll pay, of course!

speaker: Woman
text: AHHHH! A sub-human! You're a sub-human!  P-please! You can have this. Please don't eat me!

speaker: Oscar
text: No, I'm beorc. Just like you. Besides, laguz don't eat people.

speaker: Oscar
text: It's not a nice rumor to spread around. You should really try to be more thoughtful.

speaker: Woman
text: Are you...Oscar?

speaker: Oscar
text: Huh?

speaker: Woman
text: It's you! Oscar, I'm so glad to see you!

speaker: Oscar
text: Um, excuse me, I have to go...

speaker: Woman
text: Don't go! Please! Wait! Oh...

speaker: Woman
text: AHHHH! A sub-human! You're a sub-human!  P-please! You can have this. Please don't eat me!

speaker: Boyd
text: Hey, wait a second. When did laguz ever eat beorc? Have you ever actually seen it happen?

speaker: Boyd
text: Hmph. I doubt that any laguz would eat such a bigoted beorc, even if you asked for it. You make me sick.

speaker: Woman
text: Are you...Boyd?

speaker: Boyd
text: Huh?

speaker: Woman
text: It's you! Boyd, I'm so glad to see you!

speaker: Boyd
text: Uhhhh...

speaker: Woman
text: How you've grown... You look just like your father.

speaker: Boyd
text: No! You've got it all wrong! I don't know anyone by that name. I, um, have to go.

speaker: Woman
text: Don't go! Please! Wait! Oh...

speaker: Woman
text: AHHHH! A sub-human! You're a sub-human!  P-please! You can have this. Please don't eat me!

speaker: Rolf
text: But... I'm not a laguz.

speaker: Rolf
text: You might not believe me, but laguz don't eat people. I just thought you should know.

speaker: Woman
text: ...I'm sorry. I was just so scared. I didn't mean any harm.

speaker: Rolf
text: Oh... Well, it's all right. As long as you understand now, OK?

speaker: Woman
text: I'm such a coward. I can't believe it...

speaker: Rolf
text: Wait...

speaker: Woman
text: What is it? Is there something on my face?

speaker: Rolf
text: I thought you looked like someone I knew, but...it's just my imagination. I better get going. Good-bye!

speaker: Woman
text: Hey, wait!

speaker: Rolf
text: Yes?

speaker: Woman
text: Here. Take this.

speaker: Rolf
text: For me? Why?

speaker: Woman
text: I don't know... No reason, I suppose. I just thought you should have it.

speaker: Rolf
text: ...No thanks.

speaker: Woman
text: What? Wait! Oh...

speaker: Woman
text: AHHHH! A sub-human! You're a sub-human!  P-please! You can have this. Please don't eat me!

speaker: Rommit
text: We're under attack! By the goddess, they're fast! Where are our reinforcements?!

speaker: Rommit
text: When did sub-humans learn to wield swords? Impossible! I can't believe my eyes.

speaker: Ike
text: You underestimate them.

speaker: Rommit
text: No... We've lost the gate!

speaker: Ike
text: Are we clear? Good work, everyone. Open the gate!

speaker: Gallia
text: The gate is opening!

speaker: Skrimir
text: Ah, finally! Soldiers of Gallia! Follow me! As long as I lead you in battle, we will always win! Crush any who stand in your way!

speaker: Ranulf
text: ...Phew. Great timing, Ike.

speaker: Ranulf
text: We won last night's battle thanks to you guys. I appreciate your help.

speaker: Ike
text: You should be thanking Soren. It was all his idea.

speaker: Ranulf
text: Yeah, I'll get right on that. ...Hey, I just remembered. Some of your old friends are here to see you.

speaker: Ike
text: Hm?
Hey! Over here! Long time no see, Commander Ike.

speaker: Ike
text: Muston! You came!

speaker: Muston
text: It's great to be doing business with the Greil Mercenaries again. And with you too, my feline friend.

speaker: Ranulf
text: Oh, you called them out here? I thought they just smelled a battle and sensed the profits!

speaker: Ike
text: Well, we can't fight naked, like you laguz can. I also asked Muston to call on some other friends to come join up as well. You'll be seeing an increase in your forces real soon here, Ranulf.

speaker: Ranulf
text: Thanks for everything, Ike. You've done so much for us already, and now you do all this...

speaker: Ike
text: Listen, when we fought Daein, Gallia came to Crimea's aid without any questions. Now we're returning the favor, that's all.

speaker: Ranulf
text: ...All right. In any case, you guys are a great help. Thank you so much.

speaker: Rolf
text: No, no, no! On the battlefield, nothing is more important than precision and skill!

speaker: Boyd
text: Nah. Sorry, kiddo. Power is the most important element.

speaker: Rolf
text: You don’t know what you’re talking about. It’s skill!

speaker: Boyd
text: It’s power! Did you practice being this stupid?

speaker: Rolf
text: Idiot meathead!

speaker: Boyd
text: What?! Take that back, you little brat!

speaker: Mist
text: Stars above, don’t you two ever stop fighting? You’re siblings. Be nice to each other. So, what is it this time?

speaker: Rolf
text: You be the judge, Mist. What’s the most important quality a soldier can have in battle?

speaker: Boyd
text: It’s power, but little Rolfie here insists that it’s skill.

speaker: Rolf
text: If you don’t have skill, you can’t hit your enemies!

speaker: Boyd
text: If you’re weak, you can’t hurt ’em, even if you do hit ’em!

speaker: Mist
text: Oh, you two are ridiculous.

speaker: Rolf
text: Ridiculous?

speaker: Boyd
text: Yeah, whaddya mean by that?!

speaker: Mist
text: Skill and power are both important. Only a bad soldier would focus on one over the other.

speaker: Rolf
text: That’s true, but…

speaker: Boyd
text: You could at least play along a little.

speaker: Mist
text: Play along? I’m sick and tired of having to listen to your silly arguments! Anyhow, I’m here to give you something. Here you go, Boyd.

speaker: Boyd
text: Hey, thanks!

speaker: Rolf
text: What’s that? A shirt?

speaker: Mist
text: Yep. Boyd’s just like Ike. He keeps growing like a beanstalk! If we didn’t constantly make his clothes bigger, he’d run out of things to wear.

speaker: Boyd
text: I’m too broke to buy new ones. Thanks for fixing it up, Mist. I really appreciate it.

speaker: Mist
text: Well, I can’t sew very well, but it gets the job done.

speaker: Boyd
text: That it does!

speaker: Rolf
text: I thought Oscar fixed our clothes…

speaker: Mist
text: He’s been busy, so I offered to take over some of his chores. Rolf, I can alter your clothes, too. If you want, I mean.

speaker: Rolf
text: No thanks. I can do it myself.

speaker: Mist
text: Really? Well, all right, then.

speaker: Boyd
text: Like he needs alterations! I don’t think he’s grown in years. Right, short stuff?

speaker: Rolf
text: Shut up, meathead!

speaker: Boyd
text: Why you little--!

speaker: Mist
text: Hey, cut it out!

speaker: Mist
text: Rolf, wait!

speaker: Boyd
text: Yeah, you’d better run, you moss-headed twerp!

speaker: Mist
text: C’mon, you guys…

speaker: Gatrie
text: …Oh, and this girl! You’re going to think you’re dreaming! She’s as lovely as the dawn, I’m telling you!

speaker: Shinon
text: All right, just show me already. Where is this sunrise with legs, anyway?

speaker: Gatrie
text: Wait, are you saying you’re actually curious? I never thought I’d see the day.

speaker: Shinon
text: Well, we’re gonna have to hang around these sub-humans for quite a while. A pretty face will help keep me sane.

speaker: Lyre
text: Hey! You! You want to say that again?!

speaker: Gatrie
text: Ahh…!

speaker: Shinon
text: Hey, pussycat. You should’ve dropped by after dinner. I’m a generous man. I would’ve given you some table scraps.

speaker: Lyre
text: T-table scraps?! How dare you! You scum! Who do you think you are? I’m not going to forget that!

speaker: Shinon
text: Aw, kitty wants to play? Sure, I’ve got some time to kill. Let’s dance, hairball!

speaker: Lyre
text: HISSSSSS!!!

speaker: Kyza
text: Stop! Don’t make another move.

speaker: Lyre
text: Kyza! You should hear the garbage he’s saying! He’s the worst man I’ve ever met!

speaker: Kyza
text: He’s a beorc, Lyre. Please accept my apology on behalf of my associate. Please, forgive her. Now you, Lyre. Apologize to him.

speaker: Lyre
text: What?! Why do I have to be the one to apologize?! That guy was the one who started it!

speaker: Kyza
text: Do you want me to report to Captain Ranulf that you couldn’t control your temper and started a fight with a beorc?

speaker: Lyre
text: N-no…

speaker: Shinon
text: I’m waiting… I’d forgive you if you apologized. I am a nice guy, you know.

speaker: Lyre
text: What?! Never! You’re lucky I don’t claw that smile off your face!

speaker: Kyza
text: Lyre! I’m sorry… Maybe some other time. Excuse us.

speaker: Shinon
text: Hmph, I hate it when sub-humans like him act all high and mighty, pretending to be just like us beorc. He’s even worse than the other hairball.

speaker: Gatrie
text: …Sigh.

speaker: Shinon
text: What, did all that stun you into silence? You look like you’ve been hit in the head.

speaker: Gatrie
text: So, her name is Lyre. What a pretty name! Lyyyyyre…

speaker: Shinon
text: What? Oh, come on! Don’t tell me the girl you were talking about is that pussycat!

speaker: Gatrie
text: Don’t mock me, Shinon! This is serious. I feel it. It’s destiny! That girl and I are fated to be together!

speaker: Shinon
text: You’re chasing after a laguz now? Gatrie, I swear you’d hit on a tree if I dressed it in a skirt. Tell me I’m wrong!

speaker: Mia
text: There you are, Commander! I found ya!

speaker: Ike
text: What can I do for you, Mia?

speaker: Mia
text: What do you think? I only come to you for one thing… Commander! I challenge you!

speaker: Ike
text: Again? Haven’t you had enough?

speaker: Mia
text: Not at all. I was pretty close to beating you, last time. So c’mon! The longer we wait, the less I’m gonna remember about how I got that close!

speaker: Ike
text: You know I’m not going to go easy on you, right? Or on anyone else who comes at me with a sword, for that matter.

speaker: Mia
text: Good! I like it that way! That’s why I love training with you.

speaker: Ike
text: At least you’re getting something out of it. Titania and Mist just complain afterwards.

speaker: Mia
text: Don’t you worry about that! I’ve got the perfect solution.

speaker: Ike
text: What’s that?

speaker: Mia
text: Yoo-hoo! Rhys, over here!

speaker: Ike
text: Oh, I see. Interesting idea.

speaker: Mia
text: He’ll fix me right up if I get hurt. What do you think of that, huh?

speaker: Ike
text: You all right with that, Rhys? I know you don’t like watching allies cut each other up in training.

speaker: Rhys
text: That’s true, but… I think it’s better that I know how the injury happened, rather than having someone just show up and bleed on the floor. It will reduce the shock of seeing all that blood, you know? That’s something I learned the hard way.

speaker: Ike
text: Well, as long as you’re all right with it, I guess it’s fine with me, too.

speaker: Mia
text: That settles it! The scene is set, the arena ready… Prepare yourself, Commander!

speaker: Ike
text: Oh, I already have. Get ready!

speaker: Rhys
text: Just… Please go easy on each other. All right? Did you hear me? Hello?

speaker: Aristocrat
text: So, you have acknowledged Pelleas as the newly crowned king of Daein? Your Majesty, this is beyond the pale!

speaker: Elincia
text: I have not forgotten our war with Daein. Three years is not so long as that. But do not forget... If we allow hatred to rule our hearts, we become prisoners of our past. A lasting peace serves both nations.

speaker: Aristocrat
text: Bravo, Your Majesty, well spoken indeed. Your words paint a picture of idealism rarely seen here at court. However, and I beg your forgiveness, it is quite apparent your grasp of politics remains childishly naïve.

speaker: Aristocrat
text: Abandoning rule over Daein, then reconciling with our most hated enemy... This will not do. The people will soon take their discontent to the streets.

speaker: Aristocrat
text: What's more, why choose Bastian, the count of Fayre, as your envoy? His skills in court are vital to Crimea. To send away such a key figure... Tell me, Your Highness, how exactly do you plan to rule without him?

speaker: Lucia
text: The count of Fayre himself gladly volunteered as a delegate. Her Majesty's decision was only--

speaker: Aristocrat
text: Lady Lucia, still your tongue! You are not Her Majesty. Do not presume to speak for her.

speaker: Aristocrat
text: Yes, Lady Lucia! Please refrain from speaking if you have not been directly addressed. Your familiarity with the queen does not grant you a seat in the royal assembly. Although you may have been raised as a sister to Her Majesty the queen, kindly remember your place!

speaker: Lucia
text: ...You have my apologies.

speaker: Aristocrat
text: And you, General Geoffrey. Does your loyalty to Her Majesty stem only from your unchecked emotions? Those with a taste for gossip are talking. I wonder, have you heard what the help is saying about you?

speaker: Geoffrey
text: What?! I...

speaker: Lucia
text: Geoffrey!

speaker: Geoffrey
text: Rrgh!

speaker: Aristocrat
text: At any rate, growing discontent has brought the royal family of Crimea to a crossroads of sorts. Your Highness... This is all on you.

speaker: Aristocrat
text: Indeed. Your Majesty... Whatever do you intend to do?
Queen Elincia!

speaker: Elincia
text: Marcia! How are you today? And what are you doing here?

speaker: Marcia
text: Lucia told me about those no-goodnik nobles and their chest-beating contest, so I thought you could use some cheering up. You weren't in your chambers or the garden, so I guessed you would be out here.

speaker: Elincia
text: Forgive me. I needed some...time to think. I'm sorry to trouble you.

speaker: Marcia
text: Not at all! After everything you've done for me, it's the least I could do. It was nice of you to hire me as a Royal Knight, but hiring my sponge-brained, spine-deprived brother might qualify you for sainthood!

speaker: Elincia
text: Even so, I'm afraid I may also have caused you a great number of hardships.

speaker: Marcia
text: Huh? Oh! The grief I'm getting from the nobles? It's nothing I can't handle. If you think your country has stuffed-shirt windbags for aristocracy, you should see Begnion's! When I was a Pegasus knight there, they had a new shenanigan every week! After that, the Crimean crybabies are no big deal.

speaker: Elincia
text: No, it's my fault, and I'm sorry. I'm so new at all this, even you are affected by my blunders. Sometimes, I think... Maybe I just don't have what it takes to be a queen.

speaker: Marcia
text: That's so not true! Queen Elincia, anyone can strut around in a queen hat and say she's a ruler, but you always out your people first! Look, it's not that you're doing a bad job, it's just everyone's on edge lately, with Daein getting a new king and all. People are worried that Daein'll start another war like the one three years ago, and they're taking it out on you. Just don't let those peacock-wearing nobles bug you, and remember that you don't have to go it alone. You've got friends everywhere.

speaker: Elincia
text: Thank you, Marcia. Your kind words have lifted my spirits.

speaker: Elincia
text: That's right... I'm not alone. I must be strong, for the sake of our people. As the protector of our homeland!

speaker: Marcia
text: Huh? Queen Elincia... What the heck is going on over there?

speaker: Elincia
text: Hmm?

speaker: Nealuchi
text: H-hey! How dare you harass us! Begone, insolent fools! Begone, I say!

speaker: Nealuchi
text: Fear not, my lady. This senile old bird will gladly trade his life for your protection.

speaker: Begnion
text: They say nothing is as beautiful as the herons of Serenes... Especially a royal princess! You'll fetch a pretty penny from some lord or other... And our pockets are a little light. Whaddya say, Captain?

speaker: Zeffren
text: Yes, naturally. She should prove to make a fine gift. Seize them...and mind the raven's talons!

speaker: Nealuchi
text: This is unbelievable! Stand back, you unrepentant dogs! Nealuchi does not give in easily!

speaker: Zeffren
text: Men, silence that cawing raven. Who would pay for an old crow like that, anyway? Leave him.
Stop right there!

speaker: Zeffren
text: Tch... Company. How droll.

speaker: Marcia
text: Hey, Begnion dracoknights! Are you lost, or have you just been letting those scaly fleabags do your navigating? What're you doing in Crimea's sky?

speaker: Zeffren
text: ...We've merely strayed a bit in our duties patrolling the border. Do you have a problem with that?

speaker: Marcia
text: You and your flying snakes are in violation of Crimea's sovereignty! Besides, do you have any idea who you're dealing with here, reptile breath?

speaker: Elincia
text: Marcia, stop. We cannot afford to start antagonizing the Begnion army. I am the queen of Crimea...

speaker: Marcia
text: But, Your Majesty! We can't just let these wyvern monkeys run rampant--

speaker: Elincia
text: And we're not going to. As long as they don't realize I'm the queen, we should be fine.

speaker: Elincia
text: Begnion dracoknights... You will only be warned once. Leave this area immediately! I serve the queen of Crimea. Trespassers on Crimean territory will be dealt with. No exceptions.

speaker: Zeffren
text: The queen, she says! The very queen that relied on us, the Begnion Empire, to free her nation. Imperial dracoknights are not frightened by soldiers so weak as Crimean pegasus knights. Listen up! Leave those two alone. It's the Serenes maiden we want. Do not allow her to escape!

speaker: Elincia
text: ...Looks like we'll not talk any sense into them. I suppose we have no choice. Sir Nealuchi! We're here to help you!

speaker: Nealuchi
text: I'll be! It's Her Majesty, Queen Elincia! Fate has smiled upon us! I hate to be a bother, considering it has been so long, but... Your assistance is most appreciated.

speaker: Haar
text: Yaaawn... Boy, I'm bushed. Hey, partner, you tired? How's a nap sound? You want to rest your wings a bit?

speaker: Haar
text: ...Huh? We're running late? But I'm sleepy... What did you call me? That wasn't very nice. Overgrown lizard...

speaker: Haar
text: Please tell me that's not what I think it is. Oh, this is perfect. Begnion dracoknights? Just my stinkin' luck.

speaker: Marcia
text: Hey... Look who's here! It's Haar!

speaker: Haar
text: ...Hello, Marcia. I see you're still flying about on that apple-eating hairbag.

speaker: Marcia
text: And you're still asleep at the reins of that foul-smelling... Oh, crackers! I don't have time for your nonsense! Open that one good eye of yours and take a look around, will you? Those Begnion dracoknights have invaded Crimean skies! You've got to help us save the laguz they're trying to kidnap. Well, c'mon, Haar!

speaker: Haar
text: Me? Why? I owe the queen a favor or two, but I'm not one of her soldiers.

speaker: Marcia
text: You... You cad! Does having fought together in the Mad King's War mean nothing to you?

speaker: Haar
text: Well, no, but... Look, I've got a delivery to make, and this cargo's really heavy. Sorry, Marcia. Maybe next time.

speaker: Marcia
text: NEXT TIME? You lizard-loving jerk! Would you really abandon us? What kind of man are you?

speaker: Haar
text: The kind who lives to sleep another day. Well, good luck to you. See you around.

speaker: Marcia
text: Stop! You have to stay and help! Uhm... OK, Haar, hear me out. You were an imperial dracoknight once, right? It's your job to fix this! They're your old comrades--you have to keep them in line!

speaker: Haar
text: Huh? You're not making a lick of sense, girl.

speaker: Marcia
text: Why do I have to make sense? If Jill were in trouble, I bet you'd help her! Please, please, please! C'mon, Haar! You have to help us. You have to!

speaker: Haar
text: ...Is it really all that bad?

speaker: Marcia
text: Yes! They're a tough bunch! And I'm all alone... I don't think I can manage to protect Queen Elincia. Please say you'll help... If only for the safety of the queen...

speaker: Haar
text: ...Oh, fine. I really don't have time for this... But I guess I can lend a hand.

speaker: Marcia
text: Thank you so much! I take back all the mean things I was thinking about you earlier.

speaker: Haar
text: That girl's nothing but trouble. Well, if we're going to do this, let's get it over with. Up and at 'em, partner!

speaker: Haar
text: It's been a while, Queen Elincia.

speaker: Elincia
text: Sir Haar? You are Sir Haar of Daein, correct? What are you doing here?

speaker: Haar
text: That's a question for Marcia, Your Majesty. I was passing through on a delivery run, when she hailed me and pestered me into helping you.

speaker: Elincia
text: What can I say? I'm terribly sorry. I know this is none of your affair, but...

speaker: Haar
text: You know, I always thought you were too humble for royalty. I'm surprised your underlings don't run roughshod all over you.

speaker: Elincia
text: I...I'm sorry.

speaker: Haar
text: Hey, it's no skin off my nose. Besides, anyone who's got the guts to pick a fight with the empire's OK in my book.

speaker: Elincia
text: Sir Haar, I--

speaker: Haar
text: Yeah, I got it. You can't let these scum know you're actually the queen. International relations and all that other political stuff, right? I tell you what. I'll keep your secret and treat you like a regular soldier. That means I'm not going to be watching your back, though, so you're going to have to take care of yourself.

speaker: Elincia
text: I understand. Thank you.

speaker: Zeffren
text: Now, begone with you! The skies and the heron are ours! I can't wait to see your corpse smashed across Crimea's landscape!

speaker: Haar
text: Well... If it isn't Zeffren. What brings the dracoknights into Crimean skies?

speaker: Zeffren
text: Haar?!

speaker: Haar
text: Why couldn't you just stay on patrol? Saw a pretty little heron and just had to have her, is that it? I never could decide if you were more greedy or more corrupt. Stupid was never in question, though.

speaker: Zeffren
text: Who do you think you are?! You're a traitor, just like Shiharam! The dracoknights spit on your name!

speaker: Haar
text: ...Do they now? Well, here's your chance to try the real thing.

speaker: Zeffren
text: You... You Crimeans seriously believe you can withstand the might of Begnion?!

speaker: Elincia
text: Crimea takes this sort of encroachment seriously. We will not overlook invaders in our domain. Release your weapons, and apologize for your discourtesy... Only then will we lower our own.

speaker: Zeffren
text: You have quite a mouth on you... I won't be addressed in that tone by anyone. It's time to end this farce.

speaker: Zeffren
text: Ugh... Aaaaaaaagghh!

speaker: Marcia
text: Yeah, you run, dragonbackers! And don't ever come back to Crimea!

speaker: Elincia
text: Princess Leanne, it's a pleasure to see you again. I'm sorry you had to go through all that. Are you hurt?

speaker: Nealuchi
text: Lady Leanne is very grateful for your help with those ruffians and is quite delighted to see you again, Your Majesty. Frankly, I don't think these old bones would have been up to the task of protecting the princess without your help.

speaker: Elincia
text: The most important thing is that you're both safe, Sir Nealuchi. But... What brings you here? As far as I knew, the both of you were residing in Gallia...

speaker: Nealuchi
text: It is imperative that my lady sees General Ike as soon as possible. We were traveling to the royal palace in Melior for that very purpose.

speaker: Elincia
text: That's unfortunate. Ike left Melior more than half a year ago. After that, rumor has it that he reorganized the Greil Mercenaries... Now, no one seems to know where they are.

speaker: Nealuchi
text: What?! This is most unexpected. What are we supposed to do now?

speaker: Elincia
text: Sir Ike isn't here, but... Since you've traveled all this way to Crimea, would you like to visit the royal court? I would be happy to investigate the whereabouts of the Greil Mercenaries during your stay.

speaker: Nealuchi
text: Well... We don't want to be a bother, but it would be very kind of you.

speaker: Elincia
text: To be honest, there are matters about which I must speak with Sir Ike myself. And regardless, we're always delighted to have such splendid guests as yourselves. I must tell you, however--and I am ashamed to say it--there is unrest among certain circles here in Crimea. I hope nothing will happen to disturb your visit with us.

speaker: Nealuchi
text: Un-unrest...you say?

speaker: Elincia
text: Yes. I trust, however, my protection will be enough to keep you from harm's way.

speaker: Sothe
text: Well, I guess this is over. We'd better be on our way.

speaker: Ike
text: Are you going back to Daein?

speaker: Micaiah
text: Yes. Everyone's waiting for us.

speaker: Sothe
text: We have to start rebuilding all over again. Hopefully, this will be the last time.

speaker: Ike
text: Don't say "hopefully." Make it the last time. If anyone can do it, you two can.

speaker: Sothe
text: I don't doubt it. But thanks for the vote of confidence.

speaker: Micaiah
text: Thank you, Ike. I won't ever forget you.

speaker: Pelleas
text: I'm sorry.

speaker: Almedha
text: But that's... I don't believe you! Because, see, my dear, you have the mark! Wait. Don't you have a mark?

speaker: Pelleas
text: No, Mother. Lady Almehda, is that the reason you thought me to be your son?

speaker: Pelleas
text: And that is the reason why Izuka chose me out of all the children at that orphanage.

speaker: Almedha
text: Stop! This is impossible! You are my son. I am your mother, and I say so!

speaker: Pelleas
text: Lady Almedha, your only memories of your son were of him as a baby. You yourself said so. In other words, he already had a mark, even as a child.

speaker: Almedha
text: Yes, that's so. What of it?

speaker: Pelleas
text: This mark--my mark, here--is called the "Spirits' Protection." When I was thirteen, I chose to make a pact with the spirits.

speaker: Almedha
text: What?!

speaker: Pelleas
text: When I learned that you were one of the dragon clan, I began to doubt. And slowly my doubt turned to certainty. I'm sorry, Lady Almedha. I'm sorry that, though it was never my intent, I ended up deceiving you. I'm sorry, but I am not your son.

speaker: Almedha
text: P-Pelleas...

speaker: Pelleas
text: But still... I was happy. It was fleeting, but... I knew the feeling of a mother's love. You have my thanks.

speaker: Almedha
text: I... Ah...sniff...

speaker: Caineghis
text: Ah, Ike. Your work out there was superb.

speaker: Ike
text: Hey, you aren't quite over the hill yet yourself. You know, I always wanted to go one-on-one with you, just once.

speaker: Caineghis
text: Hah. I would have expected you'd had your fill of fighting.

speaker: Ike
text: I've had enough of kill-or-be-killed to last me a lifetime. But something simpler, some way of testing our respective strengths...

speaker: Caineghis
text: You mean controlled matches, with all the little rules they have. In a peaceful world, we need such things. Especially we laguz. Without a fight now and then, we go a bit strange in the head.

speaker: Ike
text: That's the honest truth. I'd rather try to order a river to change course than stop a bunch of rampaging laguz!

speaker: Sanaki
text: Wait... Sister!

speaker: Sanaki
text: You're my older sister, aren't you?

speaker: Micaiah
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Sanaki
text: It makes sense. All the pieces fit. The galdr of release... The goddess Yune's voice...

speaker: Micaiah
text: It's true. Inside the tower, I heard the voices of many hearts, and I knew. I am descended from Lehran and Altina. Misaha, the former apostle, was my grandmother.

speaker: Sanaki
text: Yes, I thought so. In that case, my sister, please consider staying in Begnion. With your power and charisma, you could do so much good here.

speaker: Micaiah
text: No, I'm afraid I can't.

speaker: Sanaki
text: Wh-why not?

speaker: Micaiah
text: Daein is my home, and Daein needs me to help it heal and rebuild. Not Begnion.

speaker: Sanaki
text: But Begnion--

speaker: Micaiah
text: Begnion has you, Empress. You will be a just ruler. Make your country proud to have you.

speaker: Sanaki
text: Will I...never see you again?

speaker: Micaiah
text: Hardly. I think that what our countries need now is a sense of family and friendship. I ask that you sign a treaty of alliance with Daein and announce that we are equals.

speaker: Sanaki
text: I will! Of course! Once things settle down in both of our countries, that will be the first thing I do...Sister!

speaker: Micaiah
text: Thank you, Empress Sanaki. ...My dear little sister.

speaker: Ike
text: Will you be heading back to Gallia first?

speaker: Tibarn
text: We'll stop by Gallia, then wing straight on to Serenes.

speaker: Ike
text: Serenes? Why there?

speaker: Reyson
text: The Empress Sanaki has kept her promise. Serenes will be formally ceded back to us. She said we may return immediately.

speaker: Ike
text: Ah, I see. That's good to hear.

speaker: Tibarn
text: Sometimes birds change their feathers. The hawks, the herons, even the ravens. We're thinking we'll all settle down together.

speaker: Reyson
text: All this time, we've sorted ourselves by our ways of thinking and seeing and living. If we can respect each other's opinions and learn to compromise, we can learn to live together without strife.

speaker: Ike
text: I don't think it will be that easy, but it still ought to be simpler than getting beorc and laguz to treat each other decently. You set a good example, Reyson.

speaker: Tibarn
text: All the major issues look like they'll be handled soon. The only thing we can't agree on is hunting and eating meat.

speaker: Reyson
text: The forest creatures are off-limits! Needless displays of violence as well. You know we will not budge on that.

speaker: Tibarn
text: Tell me... Have you ever heard of a vegetarian hawk? Or a raptor that doesn't scream victoriously at the skies after a kill?

speaker: Ike
text: Meat, huh? That's a thorny problem...

speaker: Ike
text: Well, Your Majesty. Shall we be off?

speaker: Elincia
text: Yes, let us. To Crimea. To our homeland.

speaker: Almedha
text: You are Ike, of the Greil Mercenaries?

speaker: Ike
text: And you're the dowager queen of Daein. I heard some of what you've gone through. I'm glad that you're safe.

speaker: Almedha
text: Ah, indeed.

speaker: Ike
text: In light of that... Can I do anything for you?

speaker: Almedha
text: I think not. I think I have seen enough.

speaker: Ike
text: As you wish. Well then, Lady Almedha, Prince Kurthnaga. Take care of yourselves.

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: Yes. And you as well. I know we shall meet again!

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: Are you satisfied, my sister? You wished so strongly to meet with General Ike.

speaker: Almedha
text: I only did so because Pelleas said... He said that it would be wise if I were to meet with him.

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: Did he say why?

speaker: Almedha
text: That child, he said. It was the last gift he could give me. He wouldn't say anything more.

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: A gift? By meeting General Ike?

speaker: Almedha
text: What about that beorc could possibly be... Wait... Ah! Wait! Wait, stop a moment!

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: Sister!?

speaker: Soren
text: Yes? You needed something?

speaker: Almedha
text: You are... What is your name?

speaker: Soren
text: Soren.

speaker: Almedha
text: I-I see. That...that is a fine name.

speaker: Soren
text: Thank you...?

speaker: Almedha
text: You're welcome.

speaker: Soren
text: Is that all?

speaker: Almedha
text: Ah, yes, yes. Pardon me. Calling out to you like that... I was confused.

speaker: Soren
text: Don't let it trouble you. If you'll excuse me.

speaker: Almedha
text: I don't believe it.

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: That boy is the staff officer for the Greil Mercenaries. What made you call out to him like that?

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: Sister?

speaker: Almedha
text: Because I have lost the power of my birthright, I thought... Maybe I wouldn't be able to... That I might not be able to recognize my own child. But when her own true son stands before her, no mother could fail to know. Oh, my son, you've lived and grown strong.

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: You can't mean... Soren is your son?

speaker: Lehran
text: Welcome home.
Could it be that you were here all this time?

speaker: Lehran
text: Alas, no, I am sorry to say. But for several days, I've somehow felt as though you would soon return.

speaker: Ashunera
text: Well, I'm home. And I'm glad to see you again, Lehran.

speaker: Lehran
text: And I am glad to see you as well, Goddess Ashunera.

speaker: Ashunera
text: How long has it been? A hundred years? Five hundred?

speaker: Lehran
text: About twelve hundred years.

speaker: Ashunera
text: I see. For mortals, that is many, many lives.

speaker: Lehran
text: Yes. The peace we once had is on the verge of crumbling again.

speaker: Ashunera
text: That is unfortunate. The miasma of war is beginning to shroud the world. However, I shall not again be frightened. As one born of the hopes of man I shall protect this world.

speaker: Lehran
text: Yes.

speaker: Ashunera
text: Lehran. I've missed your songs. Would you sing for me now?

speaker: Lehran
text: I...I no longer...

speaker: Ashunera
text: Well, then I will sing. And you may sing with me. Is that all right?

speaker: Lehran
text: ...Yes.

speaker: Nailah
text: A blood pact? A piece of parchment forced you into this hopeless war?

speaker: Rafiel
text: How terrible... I'm sorry for what you've been put through, Micaiah.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: The uprising in the empire continues. The apostle's people await her return as they fight against the senate. Casualties mount each day... We know how urgently the apostle's army needs to reach the empire. However, if we let their army pass through Daein, the senate will surely invoke the blood pact and destroy us.

speaker: Rafiel
text: But why haven't you told the apostle's army all this? Surely an alliance between your army and theirs could overcome the senate!

speaker: Tauroneo
text: Attacking the senate is not an option for us. If it were, we would have marched against them when this all started. If we were to side with Ike, the senate would use the curse against us. The death of the senate will not stop the curse.

speaker: Sothe
text: No matter what happens, the end result remains the same: the obliteration of Daein.

speaker: Rafiel
text: What tragedy... Is there any hope for Daein at all?

speaker: Micaiah
text: There is... One person who holds a glimmer of hope for all of us.

speaker: Micaiah
text: Queen Almedha! Queen Almedha... What do you know about the blood pact? You know some thing, don’t you? I saw the look on your face... You noticed something even before Pelleas told us about the pact. If there’s something you know that we don’t, please tell us!

speaker: Almedha
text: Heh heh...hmph...

speaker: Micaiah
text: L-Lady Almedha?

speaker: Almedha
text: Haven’t... Haven’t you done enough already? It’s done, finished. Nothing matters anymore...There’s nothing we can do. My Pelleas... My Pelleas is...

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: Almedha! Get ahold of yourself!

speaker: Almedha
text: Kurth?

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: I can’t pretend that I know what you’re going through, but, for Pelleas’s sake, you must control yourself. Remember that your son made his final sacrifice in order to protect the people of Daein! Honor his memory now and help us.

speaker: Almedha
text: ...Sniff... You’re right, Kurth. I’ll try.

speaker: Micaiah
text: Oh, thank you, Lady Almedha! Now, what can you tell us about the blood pact?

speaker: Almedha
text: ...In the Begnion era, year 626, a terrible plague swept through Daein, killing over a thousand people.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: I remember the horror of that disease. King Ashnard took the throne after the plague killed most of the royal family, including his father.The tragedy is still fresh in my mind.

speaker: Almedha
text: That was no disease. It was the curse of a blood pact.

speaker: Micaiah
text: What?!

speaker: Almedha
text: It was all plotted by my husband in a bid to claim the throne of Daein. Ashnard tricked his father into signing a blood pact with a traveling wise man. Ashnard convinced the king that he was signing a contract to procure the services of the wise man, which was true, in a fashion. With the pact signed, Ashnard had the wise man invoke the curse. My husband looked on in triumph as the royal family began to wither. The power of the curse killed every royal in line for the throne. It was brilliant. With no one to block his way to the throne, Ashnard executed his master stroke. He killed his father and took the crown from his head.

speaker: Micaiah
text: King Ashnard killed his own father? The king of Daein?! And what about the others? A thousand people died for his insane plot!

speaker: Almedha
text: There’s no point in dwelling on old wounds. Besides, the peasants didn’t matter. They had no vision. Ashnard, on the other hand... What’s important is what happened after the king’s death. Ashnard wasn’t cursed by the blood pact.

speaker: Micaiah
text: He wasn’t cursed? How is that possible?

speaker: Almedha
text: In order to break the curse of the blood pact, two conditions must be met. The destruction of the document itself, and the death of the one bound to it. Either condition by itself is not enough. I watched it happen. Ashnard killed his father, then tore apart the pact. And before my eyes, the mark of the pact faded from the dead king’s arm.

speaker: Almedha
text: The destruction of the document, and the death of the one bound...

speaker: Micaiah
text: How could you, Almedha? How could you not tell us? You knew all along--

speaker: Almedha
text: Because I was terrified! I knew that once you found out the truth, you would butcher my dear son to save your doomed country! I would have done anything to save my Pelleas... That’s why I didn’t say anything... How could I? In the end, though...it wasn’t enough.

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: Almedha, you are stronger than this. You were always the brave one when we were young.

speaker: Almedha
text: Huh?

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: I know you grieve, but grieving will not bring Pelleas back. Now is the time when you must be strong. To put Pelleas’s spirit to rest, help carry out his dying wish, and ensure the safety of his homeland.

speaker: Almedha
text: But he was... He was everything to me... How can I go on without him?

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: I am still here, dear sister. You still have family.

speaker: Micaiah
text: Sister? Lady Almedha is your sister?

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: I received your message, my sister, and have come to help. Please, Almedha, allow me to protect Daein for you and for Pelleas. Do not lose hope. You are not alone anymore and never shall be again.

speaker: Almedha
text: Oh, Kurthnaga, thank you! I’m so sorry for everything I put you and Father through... I’m so sorry...

speaker: Micaiah
text: Queen Almedha! Queen Almedha... What do you know about the blood pact? You know something, don't you? I saw the look on your face... You noticed something even before Pelleas told us about the pact. If there's something you know that we don't, please tell us!

speaker: Almedha
text: I... I know nothing...

speaker: Pelleas
text: Mother... Please tell the truth.

speaker: Pelleas
text: Mother, if you can't help us, then there's no hope for Daein. I guess we were right... We have no choice but to wager my life.

speaker: Almedha
text: Pe-Pelleas! Wait! Just wait! I'm going to tell you something... But you mustn't tell the others. In the Begnion era, year 626, a terrible plague swept through Daein, killing over a thousand people.

speaker: Pelleas
text: Yes, including nearly the entire royal family. Those who had ruled and those destined to do so--none were spared except Ashnard, who ascended the throne in the wake of it all. I've heard that tragic story for as long as I can remember.

speaker: Almedha
text: That was no disease. It was the curse of a blood pact.

speaker: Pelleas
text: What?!

speaker: Almedha
text: It was all plotted by my husband in a bid to claim the throne of Daein. Ashnard tricked his father into signing a blood pact with a traveling wise man. Ashnard convinced the king that he was signing a contract to procure the services of the wise man, which was true, in a fashion. With the pact signed, Ashnard had the wise man invoke the curse. My husband looked on in triumph as the royal family began to wither. The power of the curse killed every royal in line for the throne. It was brilliant. With no one to block his way to the throne, Ashnard executed his master stroke. He killed his father and took the crown from his head. What's important is that, after killing his father, Ashnard was not cursed himself.

speaker: Micaiah
text: He broke the pact's curse?

speaker: Almedha
text: In order to break the curse of the blood pact, two conditions must be met. The destruction of the document itself, and the death of the one bound to it. Either condition by itself is not enough. I watched it happen. Ashnard killed his father, then tore apart the pact. And before my eyes, the mark of the pact faded from the dead king's arm.

speaker: Pelleas
text: The destruction of the document, and the death of the one bound...

speaker: Micaiah
text: How could you, Almedha? How could you not tell us? You knew all along--

speaker: Almedha
text: Because I was terrified! I knew that once you found out the truth, you would butcher my dear son to save your doomed country! I would rather watch all of Daein perish than lose my Pelleas...

speaker: Pelleas
text: Mother... Thank you. Thank you for telling us. It makes my decision much easier. I will save Daein...

speaker: Almedha
text: No! I won't let you die! You are all I have left in this world, Pelleas! If you only knew how much I've sacrificed for you... I never should have said anything. I can't bear to lose you again, Pelleas... Please don't die.

speaker: Pelleas
text: I'm sorry, Mother. My mind is made up. This has to happen.

speaker: Almedha
text: Then I shall die as well! I will take my own life, if necessary!

speaker: Pelleas
text: Mother?!

speaker: Micaiah
text: ...Kurth?

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: Stop! Please, Sister. You must calm down.

speaker: Pelleas
text: Sister?

speaker: Almedha
text: Oh, Kurth... Don't you understand? I can't feel this way any longer!

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: I do understand, Almedha...more than you realize. Everyone, as you've heard, there are two conditions to breaking the blood pact: the destruction of the physical document and the death of the pact-maker. However, it takes two parties to make a pact.

speaker: Micaiah
text: Oh...I see.

speaker: Almedha
text: Yes! Ashnard once told me he'd considered killing the man who created his father's blood pact instead! I didn't know why until now... This means that we could kill the senator who signed the pact instead of Pelleas!

speaker: Micaiah
text: It's possible, but very difficult. We'll need not only to hunt down the senator, but find the document, with no idea where to start. Daein could be annihilated in the time it would take to look.

speaker: Almedha
text: Oh, Kurth! Please, please save my Pelleas! I need your help! Help me protect Daein until we get our chance to break the blood pact! I no longer have any power of my own. You're my only hope now, little brother. Please, Kurth...

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: Of course, my dear sister. That is why I came when you called me. I shall protect Daein for you and for Pelleas. So please. Put your mind at ease.

speaker: Almedha
text: Oh, Kurth, thank you! I'm so sorry for everything I put you and Father through... I'm so sorry...

speaker: Ena
text: Sir Ike... I've just received a very disturbing message from Prince Kurthnaga.

speaker: Ike
text: Don't tell me... No luck, right?

speaker: Ena
text: It is far worse than that. Prince Kurthnaga has decided to fight for Daein.

speaker: Ike
text: What?! Why? He was supposed to stop them from fighting! And now he wants to fight us instead?! Oh, this is just perfect!

speaker: Ena
text: He has a good reason to side with them, but... I'm afraid I cannot tell you why.

speaker: Ike
text: Wonderful! So we still have to fight Daein, and they've added one of the supposedly neutral dragons of Goldoa to their army?

speaker: Ena
text: I'm sorry, Ike. I will try to reason with Prince Kurth again. It was the prince's wish to come here... King Dheginsea knows nothing of this visit. Be that as it may, for a prince of the dragon tribe to stand on a battlefield... It is unacceptable. I must talk him out of it.

speaker: Ike
text: I'm sorry, Ena. I know you're doing your best to... Wait, are you talking to him with that stone?

speaker: Ena
text: Yes. We dragons have the power to sense the presence of our allies. If that ally is someone we care for very much, then we can communicate telepathically. With the sending stone, we can use this telepathy across extreme distances.

speaker: Ena
text: I just hope he listens to me. We can't afford to fuel the flames of the Fire Emblem.

speaker: Ike
text: It's almost dawn. Do what you can to convince the prince to stay out of this. I would've preferred to avoid a fight, but once again Micaiah isn't giving us much of a choice.

speaker: Ena
text: I will do my best, Sir Ike.

speaker: Daein
text: The apostle's army has left the castle!

speaker: Micaiah
text: All right. Order all units to stand by until they encounter the enemy forces.

speaker: Micaiah
text: Everyone! There is still hope for Daein! We are the key to that hope! But first, we must win this battle!

speaker: Micaiah
text: Why are you still here? You must return to the apostle's army before the battle begins!

speaker: Nailah
text: That army has enough troops. I think you could use some help on your side.

speaker: Rafiel
text: Reyson and Leanne both fight for the people they love. I shall do the same, even if that means fighting against them. I shall fight for Daein on your behalf.

speaker: Micaiah
text: Thank you both. It means a lot to me. But are you sure? After all, this seems like a hopeless battle.

speaker: Nailah
text: It's too soon for you to give up hope. You have the dragon prince of Goldoa on your side. That counts for something.

speaker: Micaiah
text: Kurth is the prince of Goldoa? So, he is a laguz...

speaker: Nailah
text: Not just a laguz. He is a black dragon. The black dragons are the strongest of all the laguz tribes. We have a chance.

speaker: Micaiah
text: If Queen Almedha's brother is a black dragon...that means the queen herself must also be a laguz!

speaker: Sothe
text: Seems like a complicated mess to me. Just the same, he is a powerful ally.

speaker: Micaiah
text: You're right. If we can stand our ground, there will be hope for another day. Each day that Daein survives is another day we'll have earned for it!

speaker: Skrimir
text: Onward, my brothers! Hold nothing back! We must end this battle quickly!

speaker: Janaff
text: Whoa, that's a problem... Uh, guys? It looks like Prince Rafiel is fighting for the other side. What do we do now?

speaker: Ulki
text: It is his choice. We can't do anything about it.

speaker: Tibarn
text: Well, his choice or not, it makes things a lot more complicated for us.

speaker: Reyson
text: He has sided with our enemies? Has he lost his mind? My dear, stupid brother...

speaker: Janaff
text: Prince! What are you doing here? What about the medallion?1 Weren't you supposed to be--

speaker: Reyson
text: Leanne is watching over it now.

speaker: Tibarn
text: Either we convince Rafiel to come back to our side, or we drag his unconscious backside over here. Got that?

speaker: Janaff
text: Yes, Your Majesty!

speaker: Ena
text: Prince Kurthnaga...

speaker: Ike
text: what will you do now, Ena? Are you going over to the other side, too?

speaker: Ena
text: King Dheginsea has expressly forbidden us from choosing sides. The dragon tribe must not fight. I shall attempt to stop the prince.

speaker: Ike
text: Do what you need to do. Just be careful out there, all right?

speaker: Ena
text: Yes, Sir Ike.

speaker: Ike
text: Elincia, please stay back. If a chance for a peace talk arises, I want you to mediate the whole show.

speaker: Elincia
text: I understand. Please be safe.

speaker: Ike
text: OK, everyone, get moving! Let's get this mess over with.

speaker: Zihark
text: There's no time to dwell on our sorrow.

speaker: Zihark
text: I must not think... The enemy in front of me is the only thing I will focus on.

speaker: Zihark
text: Ike, I'm sorry, I... I must raise my sword against you.

speaker: Ike
text: Zihark, what's going on here? Why do you sound so desperate? This isn't like you at all!

speaker: Zihark
text: I'll take my secret to the grave. Besides, you know I don't like to complain. At your ready, Commander.

speaker: Zihark
text: Micaiah! Pull back your troops! We don’t want to fight you. There’s got to be a way to stop all this!

speaker: Micaiah
text: I can’t, and there isn’t. We have to keep fighting. Until the last of us falls, we have no choice.

speaker: Zihark
text: What’s happened to you all?! Why get yourselves into such a hopeless war? Why did you do those horrible things in the valley? I know all of this must have a reason! Please tell me... Tell me how my country lost its soul.

speaker: Micaiah
text: I’ve nothing to say to you.

speaker: Zihark
text: I see. No words to waste on a deserter like me, is that it? I’m sorry I wasted your time.

speaker: Micaiah
text: Zihark--

speaker: Zihark
text: No, please... Just know that I could never draw steel against you. Good-bye, Micaiah.

speaker: Micaiah
text: I... I’m so sorry, Zihark. I can’t get you involved in this, too.

speaker: Jill
text: Lady Micaiah! Why do you insist on continuing this fight?!

speaker: Micaiah
text: Jill...

speaker: Jill
text: Even now, Daein blood spills on the battlefield. You must stop this! There must be another way!

speaker: Micaiah
text: I can’t, and there isn’t. We have to keep fighting. Until the last of us falls, we have no choice.

speaker: Jill
text: Please! Listen to what I’m--

speaker: Micaiah
text: Apostle’s dracoknight. Leave here immediately. I warn you only once. Next time, I will attack!

speaker: Jill
text: Lady Micaiah! Please, I beg of you! Lady Micaiah!

speaker: Reyson
text: The Maiden of Dawn... Lady Micaiah. I would speak with you. You are not an evil person. I already know that.

speaker: Reyson
text: That is why I am puzzled. Why do you continue to fight? Would you have your country destroyed like this?

speaker: Reyson
text: Please, say something. You have the power to end all of this violence. Say the word, I beg you!

speaker: Micaiah
text: Please go. The people of the Serenes are not safe from the chaos set loose upon us. This place isn’t safe for you. Take Rafiel with you and leave the battlefield as soon as you can.

speaker: Reyson
text: That’s all you have to say? Your men die all around you, while you stand here giving me orders? So be it.

speaker: Micaiah
text: What’s that? Who’s talking?

speaker: Micaiah
text: Ungh...

speaker: Sothe
text: Micaiah! Micaiah, are you all right?!

speaker: Micaiah
text: So... Sothe...

speaker: Sothe
text: Can you hear me? Then let’s pull back! You’re in no condition to fight!

speaker: Micaiah
text: I can hear it... It’s very close...

speaker: Ike
text: Hey, what’s wrong with you? You don’t look well...

speaker: Micaiah
text: ...What? Oh, um... I’m fine.

speaker: Ike
text: Are you? How much good can you do your men if you can hardly see straight? Pull your troops back, Micaiah.

speaker: Micaiah
text: ...There’s no need. I will stay here with everyone else and fight to the end!

speaker: Ike
text: You’re very brave, Micaiah, but sometimes bravery isn’t enough to win the battle.

speaker: Sothe
text: I’m sorry, but I can’t stop now. Winning is the only way we’ll survive this.

speaker: Sothe
text: They just keep coming at us... We have to pull back. We’ll regroup and strike them again later.

speaker: Ike
text: Good-bye, Sothe.

speaker: Sothe
text: Commander.

speaker: Astrid
text: Oh... It’s you, Sothe. I’d sincerely hoped we wouldn’t meet like this.

speaker: Sothe
text: Me too, Astrid.

speaker: Astrid
text: I knew you were with the Daein army, but I hoped that, if I didn’t see you, I could pretend it wasn’t true. Now, however, I’m glad I saw you. How you have grown. You look like a true soldier now.

speaker: Sothe
text: ...I’m not the only one who’s grown. You look every bit the true knight now, Astrid.

speaker: Astrid
text: You really think so? Thank you, Sothe. That means a lot to me.

speaker: Sothe
text: I know the answer, but I still have to ask. Will you pull back? We don’t really have to do this, do we?

speaker: Astrid
text: I was about to ask you the same thing. I don’t want to fight you, Sothe. Please fall back.

speaker: Sothe
text: ...I thought as much. Let’s get started. I’m sorry, Astrid.

speaker: Astrid
text: I am sorry as well, Sothe.

speaker: Ilyana
text: Hello, Sothe. Shall we get started?

speaker: Sothe
text: Uh, I thought you’d hesitate to fight me. I’m... a little surprised.

speaker: Ilyana
text: You’ve made your choice, Sothe, and I’ve made mine. It’s really that simple, isn’t it? Anyway, I’m starving. If I don’t eat something soon, I think I’ll pass out...

speaker: Sothe
text: Well, we can’t have that. Ready when you are, Ilyana.

speaker: Jill
text: Sothe, I--

speaker: Sothe
text: Let’s cut the small talk, Jill. We both fight for the side we believe in. There’s no point in talking things over. Let’s finish this.

speaker: Jill
text: You’re right... Let’s just get past this.

speaker: Sothe
text: I’ll forget about our time together during the Mad King’s War and the Daein Emancipation. You should do the same. We should fight without reservation and without sentiment.

speaker: Zihark
text: I agree, Sothe. I do hope you survive, for Micaiah’s sake. But you’ll have to defeat me first.

speaker: Zihark
text: General Tauroneo! Finally, I found you! Please, tell me what happened to Daein! Why are you fighting?

speaker: Tauroneo
text: There is nothing to say. We have parted ways. That is all.

speaker: Zihark
text: What are you trying to hide?! Daein has now committed atrocities on par with those committed by Ashnard! I want to know why you’d continue to fight a war like this!

speaker: Tauroneo
text: And I say that there is no need for you to know. Mercenary Zihark, return to your allies in the apostle’s army.

speaker: Zihark
text: I will find out what’s going on here! If my country can’t save itself, then I’LL save it! But I’ll never raise my sword against you. Good-bye for now, General. I hope our next meeting goes better.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: ...Forgive me.

speaker: Jill
text: General Tauroneo!

speaker: Tauroneo
text: Jill... I will tell you one thing. I do not blame you for leaving Daein. You must live by your own beliefs. That is what your father would have wanted.

speaker: Jill
text: But--

speaker: Tauroneo
text: I must live by my principles as well. You cannot convince me to betray my king and countrymen. I have done so once in the past, but that was long ago. Now, I intend to fight for my country to the end.

speaker: Jill
text: I understand... General.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: I am Tauroneo, a general of Daein!

speaker: Tauroneo
text: Ah, so we meet again. I won’t have mercy on you!

speaker: Tauroneo
text: As I expected. They’re too strong... We’ll need more drastic methods... And this injury is too deep... I have to retreat.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: General Ike, of the apostle’s army! I challenge you to a duel!

speaker: Ike
text: ...All right.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: I see so much of him in you... your stance, your spirit, the expression on your face... You remind me so much of Gawain. Let’s see if your swordsmanship matches your father’s!

speaker: Ike
text: Test me. You knew my father well. Tell me how I measure up.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: Rolf? Is that you? How you’ve grown. Kids always grow up so fast.

speaker: Rolf
text: General Tauroneo... You’re still fighting in the Daein army? Let’s not do this. No matter how strong you are, Daein can’t win this war, and I don’t wanna hurt you.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: You’re right, Rolf. Daein can’t win. In most ways, we’ve already lost everything. But I must fight on. Rolf, you stand on the battlefield as a man now. I won’t hold back. You shouldn’t either. Show me what you’ve learned in the last three years.

speaker: Rolf
text: OK, General, if you really wanna. But, just to tell you... Uncle Shinon’s been teaching me, so this might sting...

speaker: Tauroneo
text: Is that you, Calill? You look well! I heard you married Largo and opened a pub. How is Largo these days?

speaker: Calill
text: That fool went and lost his arm in an accident. No more fighting for him, that’s for sure.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: Oh! Well, uh, I’m sorry to hear that.

speaker: Calill
text: Oh, but he’s doing fine otherwise. A tough one, that man. Our business is doing great, and he’s married to the best woman in the world! That’s worth an arm or two, I’d say.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: Indeed. I’m glad you two are happy.

speaker: Calill
text: How about you, General? I told Largo that I’d visit you in Daein and see how you were doing.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: Me? I just... I only wish to meet a glorious end on the battlefield, fit for a general of Daein.

speaker: Calill
text: Mmm-hmm. Men are so full of it. I mean, honestly, are you even listening to how stupid that sounds?

speaker: Tauroneo
text: Wh-what do you mean--

speaker: Calill
text: What I mean is that you’re stupid. You have people who care for you on both sides of this suicidal battle. And here you are, in the thick of things, looking to throw your life away! You selfish fool! Looks like I’ll have to do this myself. I’m taking you back with me, General. The hard way.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: You have an interesting way of making your point.

speaker: Ilyana
text: ...Sigh.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: Taking a break on the battlefield? Things don’t seem to rattle you, Ilyana.

speaker: Ilyana
text: I’m not taking a break. I’m just sad I have to fight against you, General. Well, that, and I’m really, really hungry right now...

speaker: Tauroneo
text: I should’ve known. Let’s get this over with so you can get back and have something to eat.

speaker: Ilyana
text: ...General Tauroneo, I hope we can meet again under different circumstances.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: I hope so as well, Ilyana. We’ll have to see what happens.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: What a strange twist of fate that we would end up facing off against one another.

speaker: Zihark
text: Agreed. It seems that fate is cruel in lots of ways lately.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: Daein owes you, Zihark. Your efforts liberated our country. For that, you will always have our thanks. However, Daein cannot retreat from this war. We may face old friends as our enemies, but we cannot stop.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: I will not apologize for this war, and I cannot explain it to you. You should do what you must. We are two soldiers now, facing off against each other on the battlefield.

speaker: Zihark
text: ...Very well. I hope we’ll get to talk more about this later, General.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: Jill...

speaker: Jill
text: General Tauroneo...

speaker: Tauroneo
text: How tragic that we meet again as enemies. It was hard enough for me the first time.

speaker: Jill
text: I’m sorry... I--

speaker: Tauroneo
text: Raise your head. Stand tall.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: If you haven’t done anything to disgrace your family’s name, do not cast your eyes away from anyone.

speaker: Jill
text: I have not disgraced anything. I joined this army so I could avoid that.

speaker: Tauroneo
text: I know Jill. I’m envious of you. But this is the only way it can end.

speaker: Nailah
text: Being outnumbered isn’t such a bad thing. At the very least, I’ll get a good workout.

speaker: Nailah
text: The laguz of the west. I’ve been itching to test your mettle.

speaker: Nailah
text: ... Maybe... I should not have been so cocky...

speaker: Rafiel
text: Queen?!

speaker: Nailah
text: Stop squawking, Rafiel, I’ll be all right. ... It makes me happy that you worry for me as you do. But I’ll have to retreat for now.

speaker: Ike
text: Hold on a second! When did you decide to side with them?

speaker: Nailah
text: I spoke to Micaiah. She made me see her side of the conflict. Besides, she needed the extra help.

speaker: Ike
text: She must be an amazing talker. What did she say?

speaker: Nailah
text: I could tell you, but you wouldn’t really understand. The situation is quite complicated. But Daein has no way out. One side or the other will be sacrificed.

speaker: Ike
text: Queen Nailah...

speaker: Nailah
text: Don’t worry your pretty head about it, beorc hero. You and I are warriors--you of the sword and I of the fang. We understand what to do now.

speaker: Ike
text: Are you...enjoying yourself?

speaker: Nailah
text: If we can’t avoid fighting, we might as well enjoy it, agreed? Besides, I’ve been curious about your swordsmanship. You seem strong, for a beorc. Show me what you can do.

speaker: Ike
text: How could I say no to that? Ready when you are, Your Majesty.

speaker: Nailah
text: Hm. I’d always assumed that you cats were weak, but I was wrong. I’ve been watching you fight this battle. You’re really very good.

speaker: Ranulf
text: Queen Nailah, while I’m honored to receive praise from you, I’d really rather not fight you. I think I’d much rather run away with my tail tucked firmly between my legs, to be honest.

speaker: Nailah
text: Don’t be so modest, Ranulf. You’ll be a good challenge, I’m sure, and those are rare for me. Ready?

speaker: Ranulf
text: Thrown around by Skrimir, cornered by General Zelgius, and now this. Can someone tell me why I always seem to pull the short straw?

speaker: Nailah
text: ...I must confess, I’ve wanted this since I first laid eyes on you. I can hardly hold myself back right now.

speaker: Tibarn
text: Lady, the feeling is mutual. Why do you think I winged my way over here? It looks to me like we can have a nice, private time right here. No interruptions. Just you and me.

speaker: Nailah
text: Hawk King Tibarn. I think that a few more scars on your face will complete that rugged look you’re going for.

speaker: Tibarn
text: For a beautiful woman like you, I’ll gladly offer my head. Of course you’ll have to bring me down to the ground first.

speaker: Nailah
text: Challenge accepted. I think you’ll regret it once I add your feathers to my necklace, though. Oh, and let’s not tell Rafiel about this, agreed? He wouldn’t understand these urges of ours.

speaker: Nailah
text: Ah, the lion prince! You’ll give me the challenge I’m craving, won’t you? I’m having trouble finding decent enemies.

speaker: Skrimir
text: Gladly, Queen Nailah. I’ve wanted to fight a wolf ever since I heard the legends of your people as a cub. Let me show you why I am the heir to the lion king. You’d better hope you eastern laguz heal as well as we do.

speaker: Ilyana
text: Wolf Queen...

speaker: Nailah
text: Ilyana. I am not familiar with beorc magic. You might actually stand a chance, if you strike quickly.

speaker: Ilyana
text: Um, OK... But... Queen Nailah? Would you promise me something? If we both live through this, will you take me for some good Hatari cooking?

speaker: Nailah
text: Zihark... You used to fight for Micaiah.

speaker: Zihark
text: Queen Nailah. Do you fight for Daein now?

speaker: Nailah
text: Well, let’s say I’ve replaced some of the deserters.

speaker: Zihark
text: That’s right, I’m a deserter. I don’t have to defend my decision. I made the right choice.

speaker: Nailah
text: Zihark, I don’t care. These are beorc problems. What I’m interested in is you and your blade. Shall we get started? I remember you as a skilled swordsman. I’m excited to see your work up close.

speaker: Zihark
text: I don’t know if my blade can match your jaws, Queen Nailah, but I’m honored to face you. At your ready.

speaker: Jill
text: Queen Nailah! You’re fighting for Daein now?

speaker: Nailah
text: To tell you the truth, I’m interested in fighting you, Jill. An armed beorc trained to fight from the back of a wyvern... Now, that’s what I call a challenge!

speaker: Jill
text: Very well, Queen Nailah. I don’t know why you’ve switched sides, but if it’s a fight you want, you’ve found one!

speaker: Zihark
text: King Pelleas. Would you please listen to what I have to say?

speaker: Pelleas
text: Zihark. What is there to talk about? You’ve deserted your country and your people.

speaker: Zihark
text: I just don’t understand. I thought I knew you. You are a good, kind man. Why do you continue to fight for those bloodsucking senators?

speaker: Pelleas
text: I don’t want to talk about it.

speaker: Zihark
text: Your Majesty...

speaker: Pelleas
text: It doesn’t concern you anymore. You’ve abandoned Daein--and us. If you want to stop us, use your sword--not words.

speaker: Zihark
text: My sword and my allegiance do lie elsewhere now, it’s true. But I am not without honor. I will not draw my sword against the man I call my king, no matter what.

speaker: Pelleas
text: ...I’m sorry, Zihark. At least you’ll be spared from the curse of the pact.

speaker: Jill
text: King Pelleas! Please wait. I must talk to you.

speaker: Pelleas
text: Jill. I’m afraid I have nothing to say to you. You abandoned your own country.

speaker: Jill
text: No, I... Yes, I suppose that’s true. I just couldn’t understand why we would bow to the empire, after fighting so hard to free ourselves from their grasp! Why are you fighting an army that isn’t even an enemy of Daein?

speaker: Pelleas
text: You don’t need to understand.

speaker: Jill
text: King Pelleas...

speaker: Pelleas
text: Jill, you do what you think is best for you. Go your own way. But don’t return to Daein. Ever.

speaker: Jill
text: But I can’t do that! In the end, I am a native of Daein. This is where the body of my father lies. This is my home. My only home...

speaker: Pelleas
text: ...I’m sorry, Jill. But there’s no need for you to fall prey to the curse as well.

speaker: Pelleas
text: If you thought to end this battle quickly by fighting me, you have made a grave mistake.

speaker: Ike
text: You’re King Pelleas? The son of Mad King Ashnard? I expected you to be...bigger.

speaker: Pelleas
text: You are the hero of Crimea, General Ike. You killed my father...

speaker: Ike
text: It was nothing personal. Your father had to be put down. Wait, are you shaking?

speaker: Pelleas
text: I’ve never killed anyone before... I’ve never even stood on a battlefield before today.

speaker: Ike
text: Then why did you come here? Do you want to die?

speaker: Pelleas
text: I do, but it won’t change anything... I promised Micaiah that I wouldn’t run from my destiny. General Ike, you may be able to take me down easily, but I will not run!

speaker: Ike
text: Just what Daein needs...another mad king. Let’s see if you’re as tough as your father.

speaker: Soren
text: The new king of Daein, Pelleas. How convenient. I can end this farce right now. Surrender or die.

speaker: Pelleas
text: Who are you? That mark on your forehead... Is it a mark of Spirit Protection?

speaker: Soren
text: No. It’s something rather different.

speaker: Pelleas
text: But that shape... It looks so much like mine!

speaker: Soren
text: Is that so? You might still more powerful than you let on. Still, I doubt this changes anything. Prepare yourself, Pelleas.

speaker: Pelleas
text: But wait! There’s so much I want to ask you!

speaker: Pelleas
text: Ilyana... I’m sorry. If I were a better king, this wouldn’t have happened. I’m sorry...

speaker: Ilyana
text: Your Majesty, I don’t know what’s happened. All I know is that my friends are hurting each other. If that means I have to stop you to save them, then I’m going to try. I’m sorry...

speaker: Pelleas
text: Zihark... I only ever wanted to help our people. I’m sorry it came to this.

speaker: Zihark
text: So am I, Your Majesty. I don’t understand any of this, but I do know that it has to stop.

speaker: Pelleas
text: Jill, you told me once that you wished for me to become a good king for our people. I tried so hard... But I couldn’t fulfil your wish. I’m so sorry.

speaker: Jill
text: It’s all right, Your Majesty. I’d wrongly assumed that you had turned into a tyrant. Please forgive my desertion.

speaker: Pelleas
text: To die in this lonely place... It’s my fate... But... For Micaiah... I must... I...must live...

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: Don’t come near me! I can barely... I don’t want to do this! Get away!

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: Ugh... Gh... Im-impossible! I wasn’t... This can’t... Guh...

speaker: Ike
text: Prince Kurthnaga!

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: It’s so hot... I’m burning up! My body, it’s on fire!

speaker: Ike
text: Can you hear me? I guess not. Kurth, what’s happening to you?

speaker: Kurthnaga
text: I don’t want to fight... I... I don’t want to take any more lives...

speaker: Tibarn
text: Rafiel... Exactly what in the goddess’s name are you doing? You herons are making me tear my feathers out! Do you WANT to die? After all this time apart from your family, you want to die? Did that crazy wolf hit you on the head!

speaker: Rafiel
text: Tibarn, no, it’s not like that. I just want--

speaker: Tibarn
text: Hey, I know you’re worried about this Maiden of Daein. But that’s no reason to join up with the bad guys.

speaker: Rafiel
text: Bad guys? Tibarn, it’s not like that! They are not evil, and I’m not against you, or anyone for that matter!

speaker: Tibarn
text: Then explain to me what’s going on. Go ahead. I’m listening.

speaker: Rafiel
text: I...I want to help Micaiah. That’s all, really! That’s why I thought I should be by her side for this battle...

speaker: Tibarn
text: Right, then that means you’re an enemy now. Are you ready, Rafiel? You’d better hope that queen of yours taught you some fancy moves if you’re planning on surviving me.

speaker: Rafiel
text: Tibarn, I... Sniff...

speaker: Tibarn
text: H-hey, Rafiel, c’mon now. You know I wouldn’t hurt you! Sorry I scared you, all right?

speaker: Rafiel
text: Sniff...sniff...

speaker: Tibarn
text: Rafiel, stop! There’s no crying in battle! Get up, NOW! Please?

speaker: Rafiel
text: ...Uhh!

speaker: Nailah
text: Rafiel! You can’t push yourself any further. Get away from here, now! I forbid you to die before I do!

speaker: Rafiel
text: ... As you wish, Nailah. Everyone... Please, forgive me.

speaker: Ike
text: Rafiel! What are you doing? Why are you fighting for Daein?!

speaker: Rafiel
text: Please forgive me, Ike. I only wish to help Micaiah.

speaker: Ike
text: Then join back with Tibarn! If you stay here with Daein, you’re our enemy! And if you’re my enemy, then I’ll have no choice but to take you down.

speaker: Rafiel
text: But I just want to help Micaiah! I’m not against you! Please, put the sword down!

speaker: Ike
text: I don’t know how to deal with this. Rafiel, you leave me no choice. I’ll have to knock you out and drag you over to Tibarn. Maybe he’ll know how to deal with you.

speaker: Meg
text: Daddy!

speaker: Brom
text: Meg! I’m glad you’re safe and sound. How’s my baby girl?

speaker: Meg
text: I’m doin’ swell. It’s good to see you, too, Daddy.

speaker: Brom
text: Meg, can you do Daddy a favor? I don’t know what in blazes is going on, but family has gotta stick together! Why don’t you be a good little girl and mosey on over to your daddy’s side.

speaker: Meg
text: No...I can’t. I’m sorry, Daddy. Micaiah is a good person. I believe in her. I want to fight for her.

speaker: Brom
text: Well, shucks, this ain’t no good at all! I hope those higher-ups get their act together soon. But one thing’s for sure. You’re my girl. No way are we gonna fight. Not for anybody or anything!

speaker: Zihark
text: Meg, why are you still with the Daein army? They’re in the wrong, and you know it. I know it’s selfish of me to ask, but I’m pleading with you. Come with me.

speaker: Meg
text: I can’t... I’m sorry. I hope that this doesn’t get in the way of our wedding, but I can’t do that.

speaker: Zihark
text: Is it because of Micaiah?

speaker: Meg
